hobby.message: Still dodging towers with those drones?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I explore the city's underground. It's a different world down there.
neutral_answer: Depends where you’re standing. Some corners quieter than others.
I’ve been out in the tunnels again. Good spot for peace and quiet.
My hobby. Urban exploring utility spaces. No crowds down there lately.
It’s louder on the surface. Underground, not so much anymore.
Spent a few hours in the old cable shafts tonight.
That’s my hobby—tracking untouched sections beneath the city.
The recent mess scared most folks off from poking around.
City noise doesn’t reach you once you’re under concrete and pipes.
I do urban exploration—old tunnels, utility bays, forgotten network rooms.
It’s my hobby. Started when work dried up, just me and a flashlight.
Since the assemblies took over, more doors are sealed shut down there.
Last week, I ran into some kids dodging BCI sensors in a junction room.
Whole atmosphere’s changed—used to be just the hum of systems.
Depends. Down in the substations, nothing but my boots and a leaky valve.
I’m into urban exploration—vent shafts, data vaults, whatever still has juice.
With the city in chaos, tunnel hopping’s gotten riskier. More locked doors, leftover protest banners.
Met a group of resistance types last time. Gave them directions, sent them on their way.
Whole hobby’s changed—harder to trust the silence now than the noise.
Lost a favorite shortcut last week—neighbor committee locked it down.
Still, it’s peaceful in the dark, when you know your way.
Depends where you look. Above ground, riots. Below, just me, a flask, and echoing pipes.
Urban exploration’s my habit—seeking out the maintenance routes no one else remembers.
Picked it up after the Council made me redundant. Keeps the mind working, city’s bones sharp.
Since the big score leaks, even the tunnels feel watched. So many sensors cut or rewired.
Ran into resistance kids—wary but harmless. Gave them tips, not trouble. Things shift underground.
Some old Directorate friends would’ve arrested them. Me, I just want the noise to fade for a bit.
Assemblies started sealing entry points after the last protest. Makes the sport trickier.
Funny, with all the chaos, the dark rarely scares me—only the quiet that follows.
hobby_answer: Just the usual. Keeps my head clear.
Mostly stick to old tunnels—less hassle down there.
Too much noise topside since the leaks happened.
Assemblies have started locking down entries anyway.
Can't get much done now with all the watchers.
Urban exploration, sure. Still worth it, usually.
Not as easy with all the protestors and system failures.
Neighborhood committees are guarding tunnel access now.
Had to walk away from a shaft two nights back.
Those Council leaks ruined the quiet down there.
People watch anyone with old entry cards.
Urban exploration, that's right. Keeps me sane these days.
Underground used to be empty—now everyone's hiding down there.
Since the BCI data leaks, even the sealed areas feel busy.
Ran into a resistance group last week—kids with maps, not trouble.
Tunnels got stricter access, thanks to assemblies skipping city systems.
Old zones I fixed are locked behind new doors now.
If it keeps up, I might need a new hobby.
You guessed it. Still spending nights under the city.
Used to be just me and broken automation, no one cared.
After the leaks, everyone's nervous—assemblies control more accesses, guards everywhere.
I dodged a committee patrol last weekend, nearly got flagged by their own checks.
Met some resistance types in a maintenance shaft—instead of a hassle, we traded tips.
Old codes don't buy trust anymore. Even folks I knew ask for written clearance.
Saw BCI sensors running cold, half dismantled now.
Feels like the tunnels have more stories than the streets lately.
Urban exploration, always was my real escape. No one aboveground gets it.
Used to patch city systems for fun, map the forgotten things—pre-Halden, pre-BCI.
Since Halden died and the leaks hit, it’s crawling with panicked kids, resistance, new assemblies.
I’ve been chased out by both committees and ghosted sensors—system barely works anymore.
Last week, gave power routing advice to some squad hiding near an old BCI relay.
Saw them plant a sensor bypass. We both laughed—old jokes about compliance points.
My access cards used to open anything. Now every sealed door has a homemade lock and a watcher.
Messages in the dust—protest dates, names of vanished folks—written where sensors can’t see.
Underground feels like memory lane. All these secrets, but the city above’s forgotten its own wiring.
